about.title: Our Strategic Goals
about.description:
Through the 'CiviStories' initiative, we aim to protect Egyptian society from the dangers of digital disintegration by empowering families and restoring psychological and social balance.
We started from Egypt, where digital illusion threatens family and societal stability, and we aspire to launch a global cry to protect humanity from digital addiction ‚Äî by empowering families, restoring psychological balance, and building a humane digital space.

messages.title: Our Cry
messages.content:
From the heart of Egyptian civilization, we send our messages to the world:
‚Ä¢ Technology is a tool, not a substitute for humanity.
‚Ä¢ The family is the first fortress against digital collapse.
‚Ä¢ Digital awareness is a right for every individual and a duty for every society.
‚Ä¢ There is no safe future without balance between digital progress and human values.

child.title: Digital Childhood
questions: How do I protect my child from electronic device addiction?
What are the harms of screens on children's health?
How do I teach my child to use technology safely?
answers: Set specific times for device use, encourage physical and social activities, be a role model in balanced technology use.
Screens can affect vision, sleep, concentration, and social development. It's important to limit screen time according to the child's age.
Teach your child not to share personal information, use parental control tools, discuss internet risks in an age-appropriate manner.

teens.title: Teens' World
questions: How do I communicate with my teenager about social media risks?
What are the signs of social media addiction?
How do I help my child build a positive digital identity?
answers: Open an honest dialogue without judgment, share your personal experiences, listen to their concerns and interests, set clear rules through negotiation.
Withdrawal from social activities, lack of sleep, mood changes when unable to access the internet, neglecting school duties.
Encourage them to share positive content, discuss the importance of privacy, teach critical thinking about what they see online.

youth.title: Production and Youth
questions: How do I balance work and digital life?
What is the impact of digital addiction on productivity?
How do I use technology to develop my professional skills?
answers: Set clear work hours, use the Pomodoro technique, allocate device-free time for rest, use distraction-blocking tools.
Digital addiction reduces focus, increases procrastination, affects work quality, and causes mental fatigue.
Use e-learning platforms, participate in professional communities, benefit from free courses, build a digital portfolio.

marriage.title: Happy Marriage
questions: How do phones affect marital relationships?
What are the rules of digital privacy between spouses?
How do we create quality time away from screens?
answers: Digital distraction reduces emotional communication, creates misunderstandings, reduces intimacy, may lead to unjustified jealousy.
Respect partner's privacy, no spying, transparency in use, set clear agreed-upon boundaries.
Set 'device-free' times, eat together without phones, practice shared hobbies, allocate time for daily conversation.

seniors.title: Seniors
questions: How do I help my parents use technology safely?
What are the main internet risks for seniors?
How can we use technology to improve seniors' lives?
answers: Teach them step by step, use simple apps, set fraud protection, help them stay connected with family.
Financial fraud, identity theft, privacy, misinformation, social isolation despite digital connection.
Health apps and medication reminders, communicating with grandchildren, entertainment and learning, electronic services to ease life.

security.title: Security and Privacy
questions: How do I protect my personal information online?
What is the importance of strong passwords?
How do I recognize online fraud attempts?
answers: Use strong and different passwords, enable two-factor authentication, don't share sensitive information, review privacy settings regularly.
A strong password is the first line of defense against hacking. Use a mix of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols.
Beware of messages requesting personal information, verify message sources, don't click on suspicious links, use protection software.

humanVision.title: Our Human Vision
humanVision.content:
In a world racing towards limitless digitization, we call for:
‚Ä¢ Placing humans back at the center of attention.
‚Ä¢ Building bridges between civilizations through shared values.
‚Ä¢ Transforming technology from a source of isolation into a tool for communication and understanding.
‚Ä¢ Instilling digital responsibility in the hearts of future generations.
Because true civilization is not measured by screens, but by humanity.

islam.title: Islam: Balance and Moderation in Technology Use
islam.content: Islam calls for balance and moderation in all things. Moderation is a core value that protects humans from excess and negligence. In the age of technology, we need to apply these principles to protect ourselves and our families from digital addiction.

christianity.title: Christianity: Love and Human Relationships
christianity.content: Christianity focuses on love and real human relationships. Technology should serve these values, not disrupt them. Building strong relationships with family and community is the essence of Christian life.

judaism.title: Judaism: Protecting Family and Community
judaism.content: Judaism emphasizes the importance of family and community. The Sabbath (Shabbat) is an example of the importance of periodic disconnection from daily life burdens and technology to connect with God and family.

buddhism.title: Buddhism: Mindfulness and Freedom from Attachment
buddhism.content: Buddhism teaches mindfulness and freedom from attachment. Digital addiction is a form of attachment that causes suffering. Through awareness and mindfulness, we can use technology wisely.

hinduism.title: Hinduism: Balance Between Material and Spiritual Worlds
hinduism.content: Hinduism emphasizes balance between material and spiritual worlds. Technology is part of the material world but should not dominate our spiritual life and human relationships.

confucianism.title: Confucianism: Harmony and Right Relationships
confucianism.content: Confucianism focuses on harmony and right relationships in society. Respect for family and human relationships is more important than any technology. We should use technology to enhance these values.

taoism.title: Taoism: Living in Harmony with Nature
taoism.content: Taoism calls for living in harmony with nature and the natural flow of life. Excessive use of technology disturbs this natural balance. Simplicity and naturalness are the way.

shinto.title: Shinto: Respect for Nature and Ancestors
shinto.content: Shinto emphasizes respect for nature, ancestors, and community. Maintaining family and community bonds is more important than virtual communication. Technology should serve these values.

jainism.title: Jainism: Non-Violence and Compassion
jainism.content: The principle of non-violence (Ahimsa) in Jainism applies to the digital world. We must avoid harming ourselves and others through excessive use of technology or harmful content.

zoroastrianism.title: Zoroastrianism: Good Thoughts and Good Deeds
zoroastrianism.content: Zoroastrianism focuses on good thoughts, good words, and good deeds. In the digital world, we must apply these principles and use technology for good.

african.title: African Philosophy: Ubuntu and Community
african.content: The concept of Ubuntu (I am because we are) emphasizes the importance of community and human relationships. Technology should strengthen community bonds, not weaken them.

secular.title: Human Ethics: Dignity and Well-being
secular.content: Secular ethics focuses on human dignity and well-being. Using technology in a way that respects human dignity and promotes well-being is a universal moral duty.

messagesModal.title: üåç CiviStories: A Global Cry for Digital Mercy
messagesModal.content:
From the heart of Egypt, where thousands of divorces are recorded annually due to screen misuse.
Where billions of pounds are wasted between productivity losses, online fraud, and mental health treatment.
We raise our voice not just as Egyptians, but as humans who see that humanity is facing a new test.

The goal of this platform is not to blame technology, but to save the human relationship from it.

We are not asking to ban phones, but calling for their conscientious use.

Every child in Tokyo or Tripoli, in S√£o Paulo or Seoul deserves to look into their mother's eyes without a screen separating them.
Every young person in Cape Town or Kuala Lumpur deserves to build their identity from their reality, not from the illusion of algorithms.

Social media is not evil, but it is not neutral‚Äîit is a mirror of the intentions of those who direct it.
Today, if not guided by mercy, it may become the fastest way to break up families, sow despair, and push some to suicide.

For this reason, CiviStories launches:
An open human call to every government, religious, cultural, or civil institution to participate in building a digital space that protects dignity, not threatens it.

We started with Egypt‚Äîbecause honesty begins at home.
But our message is not for Egypt alone, but for the whole world.

‚ú® What we ask today:
- From parents: to return to being the first "filter" for their children.
- From governments: to establish policies that protect children from digital addiction.
- From platforms: to choose humanity over profit.
- From spiritual and cultural institutions: to guide conscience, not remain silent.
- Every reference in the world‚Äîreligious, philosophical, or humanitarian‚Äî
to join this cry, in their language, values, and vision.

> Share our message and save those you love. Protect humanity before it becomes a digital memory.
> Don't let the screen steal your child's childhood, your home's peace, or your hope in life.
